message: Hardware costs going way down. $100 gets you a 2TB drive.
Interesting that Aaron Emigh had experience at Six Apart before ShopKick
ImageShack/yfrog had problems with MySQL
They ended up moving to SSDs which helped a lot
David Michaels making a good point. It's not just "move it to the cloud" but architect properly.
@DctrWatson No, nobody brought that up, that's a good point though.
"You'd have to be crazy not to build it in the cloud"
Really interesting to hear Jack Levin talk about the growth at Google
Mint had 30x more users join then expected on its first day
They moved away from MySQL entirely, and went to HBase.
Mint says that the ACID compliance of MySQL actually is very important for them with financial data.
@ericflo they recording this?
@zeeg yea, I think so
Basically people saying product comes first, scalability comes later.
Scalability for Mint was second only to security (makes sense)
He mentions the write-through cache as being extremely effective.
@ericflo darn. Though I suppose with a good caching paradigm that really wouldn't be much of an issue
"If you're in the prototype stage, don't waste your time building up your infrastructure, just use something like Heroku"
didn't Mint just say scalability was second only to security? so product should be third right? :)
Answer: ask questions that demonstrate deep understanding, not just "how does this tool work?"
@EmilStenstrom haha, different people speaking :)
Hybrid hosting model can make sense. Bare metal for DB, virtualized/cloud for other stuff.
Jack Levin from ImageShack/yfrog talking about monitoring and how important having a great dashboard is.
Also the monitoring is smart enough to do things like cut power when components get too hot.
Don't let other people "manage" your code, it's a trap.
"Noisy Neighbor Problem" - cloud providers do a bad job of divvying up disk IO
Can get big wins by doing processing intensive tasks asynchronously, so that the website still feels responsive.
Question was: how do you actually recruit people for the startup?
Virtualization can help with this, says Aaron Emigh of ShopKick
@ericflo ah, that was going to be my next question :)
Product first, architectures evolve to meet the need
Talking about the difficulty of heterogeneous hardware. Need a good way of pushing traffic to different classes of servers.
@ericflo was latency addressed between virtualized/cloud and bare metal?
Don't spend any more than a month on the design. Get it built, then later you can iterate and change it.

You need real world traffic to see where things will really fail.  Invite limits can be a good way to do that. Simulating traffic on a test cluster is a good approach too. Or mirroring traffic onto a secondary cluster.
Answer: "I don't actually ask technical questions. I look for traits like diligence." If the guy says "I don't know HBase but in a month I'll be an expert" then he's more likely to hire that guy.
Someone asked about the panel's thoughts on the whole "DevOps" movement
Answer: Know your own product, you need to be operationally savvy about your own domain.
Apparently Mint and ShopKick are both doing this.
Answer was to always launch with two of everything, because going from 2 to 4 to 10 is way easier than going from 1 to 2.
@DctrWatson Also some hosting providers give you hybrid stuff, RackSpace for instance will put it in the same data center I think.
"I certainly wouldn't use Heroku for our systems but for prototyping and testing, sure"
Question: You should hire ops guy at your series A. Is that a good hard-and-fast rule?
Answer: Cloud is no substitute for operational savviness.
Answer: Know exactly what it is you're looking for.
Interesting comment by mint guy on java having performance issues, productivity issues, and security issues...
FIN
Also it was said to get good systems people on your team, Google won because search returned in 1sec vs. Teoma's 20secs even though Teoma had "better" results.
Question was about Heroku, is it a crutch or useful service?
Emphasis on using the same caliber of system to test load that you're using in production, otherwise the test isn't really valid.
@scottackerson anything data to back those up? =\
Answer: Developers should think about ops, Ops people should think about development technology.
Answer (Jack Levin): HBase, nginx, memcached, HAProxy
Answer (David Michaels): An amazing software engineer :)
I asked about conflicting desires to move fast & iterate quickly vs. building for scale.
Answer: it's terrible for a company to try to completely separate dev and ops, so DevOps is a good idea.
It's also important to keep your top talent interested, says David Michaels
Question: Thee favorite tools?
Thanks @ericflo
Answer (Aaron Emigh): nginx, memcached, Hadoop (HDFS, Scribe, ZooKeeper, Thrift, Hive)
@ericflo Thanks! Caught up with this topic about an hour after the live event and found a good snap shot of whats been said with an opportunity to discuss. A+ ;)
@ahmad_alibrahim I don't think so, feel free to create one :)

https://convore.com/scalability/
